Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Morphological evolution, specialization, and functional ecology in a diverse genus of ants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will address a fundamental question in biology: the mechanisms that allow many species to persist in any single environment. Ants are highly diverse in many different habitats and are important for ecological processes worldwide. To understand what promotes the persistence of ant diversity, the association between physical traits, such as spines and stings, and ecological interactions, like competition and defenses against predators, must be experimentally determined. This project will investigate one of the most widespread and commonly encountered ant groups in tropical Africa, Asia, and the Pacific, the spiny ant, Polyrhachis. Using ecological field experiments, this research will assess the effect of a wide range of anatomical defenses on ant competition and anti-predator defense. It will contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms that promote biodiversity in tropical habitats. Furthermore, this project will foster international collaborations between researchers in the U.S. and those in China. The researchers will also actively participate in numerous outreach and public engagement opportunities in Chicago, including various science education programs at the Field Museum of Natural History, and academic tutoring of middle and high school students from groups that are underrepresented in the sciences.

To elucidate the ecological selective forces driving spine adaptation and specialization in Polyrhachis, the researchers will conduct a series of competition and predator-prey experiments at the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG) in Yunnan, China. These experiments will include a range of species that are present at this site and that span the full range of spine morphology, from absent to extremely long. In the first set of tests, the researchers will assess the impact of spines on interspecific ant competition. In the second, the researchers will quantify the survival benefit conferred by spines as defenses against frog predators. These experiments will be conducted in the lab using colonies collected in the field. A common chamber design with experimental spine length manipulation will allow for differentiating the survival effects of spine length in terms of two fundamental ecological interactions. Using data from these experiments, the researchers will evaluate the evidence for an ecological trade-off between competitive ability and anti-predator defense mediated by spines. These empirical tests of the trade-off hypothesis in Polyrhachis, a remarkable animal radiation, will expand scientific understanding of the processes that promote community coexistence and ecological success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-PI Benjamin Blanchard has completed this research project for his dissertation on the evolution of defensive traits in ants, supported by the NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. During the funding period, he spent two 3-month field seasons at Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), his field site in southern Yunnan, China. In collaboration with his advisor (PI Dr. Corrie Moreau), hosts (Drs. Min Cao and Akihiro Nakamura), and field assistants (Yi Chen, Rong Lin, Runming Yang, and Nuo Yan), Blanchard investigated the potential costs and benefits of spines (thorn-like projections protruding from the exoskeleton) in the spiny ant genus Polyrhachis, a widespread and conspicuous group of 700 known species. In particular, he sought to better understand the ecological causes of spine evolution, as well as potential ecological costs of investing in spines as defensive traits.

During summer field work in 2017 and 2018, Co-PI Blanchard collected a number of colonies from various Polyrhachis species and conducted resource foraging, competition, and predator-prey trials in an XTBG lab. He found little evidence for any ecological costs, instead finding that species with longer spines either outperform or do not differ from species with shorter spines for all tested metrics. Thus, spines appear to confer both broad anti-predator benefits as well as benefits for foraging and possibly competitive ability, potentially explaining the large number of evolutionary origins of spines in ants. Blanchard has submitted a manuscript reporting these findings to a peer-reviewed ecology journal, and the manuscript is currently under review.

During the course of this project, Co-PI Blanchard developed international professional connections with his collaborators as well as several other researchers at XTBG. Three of his field assistants attended the local Pu'er University in Yunnan, China, and he trained these students in field collection and documentation methods. Furthermore, Blanchard's work on spiny ants in China was featured in a 6-month temporary exhibit at the Field Museum in Chicago, showcased in the Grainger Science Hub and viewed by thousands of patrons to the museum. Blanchard occasionally participated in this exhibit through the museum's Meet a Scientist program, sharing his work with members of the public. He also participated in an interview that discussed this work for a University of Chicago Magazine article.

The work conducted through this NSF-DDIG grant supported the entirety of one of three studies in Blanchard's dissertation, which is to be completed by the summer of 2020. Some of the specimens acquired and results found during this study will also directly contribute to his third and final dissertation study on species and trait evolution. Overall, support from this grant has advanced our knowledge of how species evolve as well as how physical traits impact important species interactions, and has shared the process of scientific study with the broader public.
